abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, though institutional development
            impacts are only modest. Lessons learned suggest that the
            project's responsiveness to the country's
            priorities generated strong commitments to project
            implementation in the initial three years, particularly
            important given Georgia's unfamiliarity with project
            procedures. However, this responsiveness to rapid
            preparation, though beneficial, encountered costs, and
            losses, such as the need to build institutional capacity, in
            particular financial discipline, transparency, and
            competitive procurement. This diversification in the lending
            portfolio led to declining Bank supervision resources,
            unable to provide the assistance needed by the borrower.
            Nonetheless, the strong, initial support by the Bank,
            provided the impulse for this investment project to move
            forward, which in hindsight, may have even prevented greater
            deterioration in project performance during the final years
            of implementation. But the application of Bank procurement
            guidelines seems unrealistic, given the country's
            recent political unrest, which conflicted with international
            procurement attempts, and, in retrospect, closing the
            project as originally scheduled, made better use of scarce
            resources, rather than extending the project to complete few
            remaining contracts, since actually, procurement was largely completed.
